Home About Me

Alina Kurjan

Computational and molecular biologist with a DPhil from Oxford, specialising in multi-modal sequencing data analysis and pipeline development. Bringing strong academic and industry experience - including roles at AstraZeneca, Entelo Bio, and in OBDS bioinformatics teaching - combined with an entrepreneurial mindset.

About me

Table of Contents

  • Alina Kurjan

Experience Work

  1. •

    Computational Scientist II

    Entelo Bio

    Nov 2024 - Present (Part-time)
    Leading the development of modular computational biology pipelines for short and long-read RNA-sequencing data analysis across different organisms and modalities.
  2. •

    Postdoctoral Research Associate

    NDORMS, University of Oxford

    Nov 2024 - Present (Part-time)
    Leading the analysis of single-nucleus and spatial RNA-sequencing human developing and aged musculoskeletal datasets for the Human Cell Atlas network. Published in Mimpen J. Y., et al. (2024) FASEB J. and Mimpen J. Y., Baldwin M. J., et al. (2025) J. Physiol..
  3. •

    Bioinformatics Teaching Fellow

    MRC WIMM, University of Oxford

    Dec 2023 - Present (Seasonal)
    Developed the 'Python for Single-cell Analysis' module for the OBDS Training Programme, delivering lectures in the theoretical background as well as advanced coding tutorials for multi-sample end-to-end data analysis. Topics include sequence alignment, quality control, data correction and integration, normalisation, dimensionality reduction, clustering, and annotation.
  4. •

    DPhil in Molecular and Cellular Medicine

    NDORMS, University of Oxford

    Oct 2020 - Oct 2024
    Investigated the cellular and extracellular matrix biology defining human embryonic, foetal and aged tendons using single-nucleus and spatial RNA-sequencing techniques, imaging, and computational biology. Uncovered cell types and pathways relevant for the design of biomaterials capable of guiding diseased/aged tendon tissue repair towards a self-regenerative phenotype.
    Supervisors:
    • Assoc Prof Sarah Snelling
    • Dr Mathew Baldwin
    • Assoc Prof Adam Cribbs
    • Prof Christopher Buckley
